Organs/Tissues: Versatile: kidney, liver, gut, skin, brain, tumor tissues, etc. The open-well + microfluidic channel approach suits many organ or tumor models.
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Normal organ function (vascular perfusion, mechanical cues) or diseased conditions (tumors, inflammation, infection).
Cell Source: Flexible: iPSC-derived organoids, primary cells, tumor biopsies, standard lines. 3D organoids or ex vivo slices. Endothelial + parenchymal co-culture.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, co-culture in open well (3D tissue) plus endothelial or different cell type in perfused channel below or adjacent.
Stromal Cells: Yes, can embed fibroblasts or mesenchyme with parenchymal cells in 3D. Endothelial lining in microchannel for vascular mimicry.
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, can incorporate immune cells in the tissue/3D construct. E.g. macrophages within tumor slice or organoid.
Circulating Immune: Yes, the perfusable channel can introduce immune cells under flow, enabling infiltration studies.
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Open well supports organoid or tissue; channel mimics vasculature. For multi-organ link, multiple comPLATE wells can be connected or used in parallel.
Air-Liquid Interface: Achievable by using single-flow top well open to air (for lung or skin). Bottom channel perfuses medium from below.
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, 3D hydrogel or scaffold can be placed in open well. The porous membrane & flow below supply nutrients.
3D Scaffold: Core feature. Organoids or tissue slices set in 3D matrix in the well. Perfusion from below prevents necrosis.
Notable Features: Open well + microchannel design. Porous membrane. Long-term perfusion. Mechanical & electrical stimulation (with expansions). Low auto-fluorescence. Standard 6-well plate footprint.
Plate/Format (Throughput): 6-well comPLATE. Each well = 1 microfluidic chip. Up to 6 parallel organ-on-chip cultures. Medium throughput vs. typical single-chip solutions.
Max Culture Duration: Days–weeks. Reports of 7–14 days for tumor slices, 9+ days for organoids with stable perfusion.
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, transparent bottom window. Compatible with inverted microscopy, confocal, real-time imaging.
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: From outflow of lower channel. The open well can also be sampled. Low volume channels => rapid solution changes.
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Easier than closed chips: 3D tissue in the well can be pipetted out or lifted. Membrane-based structure can also be removed carefully if desired.
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, entire organoid or slice can be removed post-experiment for histology. Or do immunostaining in situ.
Readouts - TEER: No integrated electrodes, but user could attempt external TEER setup. Usually rely on paracellular tracer assays or morphological integrity checks.
Readouts - MEA: Not standard, though the MUSbit variant includes electrodes for muscle/heart. inCHIPit itself doesn't have built-in MEA.
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Not by default. Possibly future expansions. Typically external sampling or imaging-based measurements. They do offer mechanical/electrical stimulation expansions for muscle.
Dead Volume: Low. Microchannel volume is minimal, ensuring efficient media usage and quick response to changes.
Perfused: Yes. Single-flow mode (bottom channel only) or double-flow (both top and bottom). Allows stable nutrient supply for 3D tissues.
Gas Mix Controlled: Place comPLATE in standard incubator for CO₂. The sealed channel environment uses pre-equilibrated media. ALI or normal submersion is user’s choice.
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate, drug dosing, and mechanical stimulation can be changed any time. If muscle or heart model: electrical pacing included in expansions (MUSbit).
model_availability: Commercial from Bi/ond. The comPLATE and inCHIPit chips are sold for standard organ-on-chip. Users provide biology, can choose single or double-flow lids.

Organs/Tissues: 3D engineered muscle tissue (cardiac or skeletal), including hiPSC-derived cardiomyocytes for heart-on-chip or muscle fiber cultures.
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Normal contractile function (beating heart tissue) or disease states (cardiomyopathies, muscular dystrophy).
Cell Source: Primarily cardiomyocytes (iPSC or primary) or skeletal myocytes. Co-culture with fibroblasts or supportive cells for mature muscle. Possibly patient-derived lines for disease modeling.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, fibroblasts or vascular cells can be integrated. The system focuses on muscle fibers but can include supporting stroma.
Stromal Cells: Yes, fibroblasts, mesenchymal cells in the muscle scaffold to promote physiological structure. Endothelial networks also possible.
Tissue-resident Immune: Less common in muscle, but feasible if user wants an inflammatory scenario (myositis). System is designed mainly for myocytes & stroma.
Circulating Immune: Possible if the user sets up a perfusable channel around the muscle fiber zone for infiltration. Not the main standard usage.
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): In principle, can combine MUSbit with another organ chip for multi-organ circuits. MUSbit focuses on muscle contraction readouts.
Air-Liquid Interface: Not typically relevant for muscle. The chip is fully perfused or partly sealed. No ALI needed for muscle tissue.
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, muscle cells embed in a 3D gel (collagen, fibrin) anchored to pillars or flexible posts to form aligned fibers.
3D Scaffold: Core concept: 3D muscle tissue with anchor points. The chip fosters alignment, supports conduction of contraction signals.
Notable Features: Electrical & mechanical stimulation for muscle training. Force measurement via post deflection. Perfect for testing inotropes or muscle diseases in vitro.
Plate/Format (Throughput): Similar to inCHIPit approach, typically 1 muscle construct per chip. Could run multiple in parallel in a comPLATE-like setup. Low–medium throughput.
Max Culture Duration: Up to weeks while the muscle matures and maintains function under repeated contractions. Perfusion prevents necrosis.
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, track fiber alignment and contractile motion via optical methods (confocal or video).
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, perfusate can be collected. For troponin release or metabolic markers, etc.
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Potentially enzymatic release from the 3D gel. Usually endpoint includes on-chip imaging or destructive sampling of tissue.
Readouts - Whole Tissue: In situ imaging is standard. Tissue can be removed if the design allows. Typically fix and stain on chip, measure force directly on pillars.
Readouts - TEER: Not relevant for muscle. No epithelial barrier. Passive electrical conduction is measured differently (MEA approach).
Readouts - MEA: Yes, partial. MUSbit has built-in electrodes for electrical pacing/stimulation, might measure field potentials. Fully integrated MEA might be partial or planned.
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Force sensing is integrated via micro-post deflection. Additional sensors (pH, O2) not standard but feasible externally.
Dead Volume: Low in microchannels. Perfusion specifically around muscle fiber zone to supply nutrients, remove waste.
Perfused: Yes, continuous flow for nutrient supply. Electrical stimulation for pacing. Possibly cyclical mechanical tension if desired.
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator environment or pre-equilibrated media. No specialized O2 exchange. Enough for muscle to survive if flow is correct.
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes. One can vary pacing frequency, apply drugs, or modify flow. Watch contractile changes in real time.
model_availability: Commercial from Bi/ond for muscle tissue research. iPSC or primary muscle cells used. Sold as an advanced add-on to comPLATE or standalone.
